Virgo, the Library’s online catalog, underwent a significant update in July 2020, from version 3 to version 4. The update was the culmination of years of work pulling together user research, internal expertise, and trends in institutional software and web development.

Why now?

The previous version of Virgo was built on now-outdated architecture and technology, and course reserves functionality was dependent on the even older “Virgo Classic”. Both of these versions — Virgo 3 and Virgo Classic — remained live until July 2020, despite neither being mobile-friendly for search and discovery. With improvements to search technology over the past few years, we knew we’d be able to deliver more effective and pleasant experiences through a fully rebuilt interface.

Though it wasn’t planned, and offered many additional challenges, the COVID-19 pandemic meant we also had a renewed urgency to better meet remote user needs through an updated interface.

Notable features of Virgo 4

  • Improved accuracy of search:
    • Materials are grouped by work.
    • Date range searching.
    • AND, OR, NOT Boolean options for more sophisticated searches.
    • Research can be limited by availability.
    • Facilitation of discovery beyond UVA collections (JMRL, WorldCat, etc.).
  • Customized results with login:
    • Make ILL requests directly from Virgo.
    • Review checkouts, renew items, and check ILL dates.
    • Save complex searches for later use.
    • Save, organize, and share bookmarked searches.
    • Set personal preferences for the interfaces.
  • More features:
    • Responsive to any screen size or mobile device.
    • Visual access to digital image collections.
    • Citation cut-and-paste in multiple styles.
    • Improved and enhanced virtual shelf browse.
    • Full featured Application Programming Interface (API) to allow direct access to data.

Where do we go from here?

Most modern software is developed in a series of continual improvements, new features, and fixes. Rather than bringing out a massive new system every decade or so, this model allows us to modify Virgo often to make UI improvements, respond to user suggestions, and implement technical upgrades.
